text: You notice people order more teh tarik in the mornings? I'm trying to figure out how to optimize breakfast delivery.
Every table is different… some like kopi, some like teh. Depends on mood, on who they sit with.
But if I know the pattern, I can scale it. That's the point.
For me, kopi is not numbers. It's how you stir, how long you pull. People taste that.
Jie, your company feels like my dance crew — chaos, everyone chasing clout.
Chaos? It's building the future. Investors, government grants — it's real, not just viral.
Real? Half your interns are burnt out. At least in dance, if we go viral once, we celebrate.
If I don't scale, we don't survive. Virality is a sugar rush. I'm playing the long game.
When I came here, also not easy. I was small, had to learn everything new. But after independence, they gave us papers. We belonged.
For me… no papers. I work, send money home. But I cannot belong. Every day I worry.
The country forgets it was built by people like us.
Ma, I try every year for citizenship. Always more forms, more tests. Feels like I'm proving myself again and again.
In my time, they needed people. They welcomed us. We sang the anthem once, and we were citizens.
Now, I live here, I married here, but one mistake — visa late, wrong stamp — and I lose everything.
Back home, we rapped against the police. Small shows, no lights, just anger and rhythm. Hip-hop was survival.
Now it's about TikTok dances, sponsorships, Nike collabs. It's how you go viral, not how you resist.
Viral is not freedom. It's just another cage.
Maybe. But it's the cage we know how to play in.
